definition[0]: a problem or disadvantage, especially one that is not very serious, which you had not expected
example[0]: It’s an interesting job. The only snag is that it’s not very well paid.
example[1]: The grand opening hit a snag when no one could find the key.
explanation[0]: Snag is slightly informal. In written English, people usually prefer to use problem or disadvantage instead:
example[2]: The only disadvantage is that it takes a little longer.
definition[1]: a part of a dead tree that sticks out, especially one that is under water and can be dangerous
definition[2]: a sharp part of something that sticks out and holds or cuts things that touch it
definition[3]: to damage something by getting it stuck on something sharp
example[3]: Oh no! I’ve snagged my stockings.
definition[4]: to succeed in getting something, especially something difficult to get
example[4]: I snagged a parking space in the last row.
